subtitle.Text: I’d already played through the first full half of Gone Home before I started composing any music, which was really important to understand how the game felt and played and looked. But I didn’t get a build of the complete game

until I’d already been delivered the part two audio logs, and then ended up not playing any of the second half of the game until it was fully complete and I’d written all the music. This wasn’t originally my intention,

but it meant I ended up fully immersed in Sam’s story, essentially to the exclusion of all the other subplots of the game, which are not accompanied by specific music. I don’t know if that was objectively the right call

or not as the composer, but it definitely made me feel very connected to that character. I probably heard Sarah delivering Sam’s story dozens or maybe hundreds of times over. It also meant I didn’t actually know the literal implications

of the ending of Sam’s story, so I was imagining all kinds of potential endings that ended up being a lot darker than what you see when you finally do reach the attic. So as a player, when I did complete the game I was pretty relieved.
